glossdef.para: The combined conditions under which a user or application is accessing content in &PRODUCTABBR;. This includes the users role(s), the education organization(s) to which the user's assigned, and the application that user's signed in to.
An object that encapsulates a user's authenticated session with an application, including their access privileges.
Reserved user role

The process used by an application developer or &PRODUCTABBR; administrator to request access to the &PRODUCTABBR;. This registration process ensures that application has both credentials to authenticate with &PRODUCTABBR; and permission to access &PRODUCTABBR; resources (REST API, Data Store, etc.).

A rule set in the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Servicewhich ties together instances of two given entities. An association may exist as an entity itself (and thus as a resource in the REST API), or it may be expressed as a direct reference under each entity it's associating.

The attribute component of the industry standard entity-attribute-value model (EAV) used to describe a data model, such as the model for the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service. An attribute is a property or parameter for a given entity. In &PRODUCTABBR;, each attribute in the Secure Data Service corresponds to the name portion of a name/value pair in the request and response bodies used in the REST API.
See also required attribute, non-required attribute.

The process of verifying that a user is who they claims to be by providing a set of accepted security credentials. For example, to authenticate with a certain system, John Smith provides a valid user name and password that matches his 'jsmith' user account.

The process of determining what resources a user has permission to access and what actions that user has permission to perform. For example, after John Smith authenticates to a system, the system authorizes him to view data associated with the students in his classes.
See redirect URI.
An ID that uniquely identifies an application to &PRODUCTABBR;. The client ID is granted by the &COMPANYABBR; during the application registration process.

A value that, in combination with the client ID, enables your application to authenticate with &PRODUCTABBR;. The client secret is granted by the &COMPANYABBR; during the application registration process.
Fields that all REST API resources have, including id (the unique identifier of the resource), entityType, and metaData.
See also standard field, view.

The combined conditions under which a user or application exists relative to data in the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service. A context for a given user is expressed as a combination of user role(s), the education organization(s) to which the user's assigned, and the application a user's currently using to interact with &PRODUCTABBR;.

A unique combination of text or digital objects used to gain access to protected content. This is typically a user name and password, though some systems might require rotating key codes or key cards.

Data associated with an entity but that isn't part of the &COMPANYABBR; data model. Developers can add this data to store data beyond what's covered in the &COMPANYABBR; schema. The &COMPANYABBR; developer documentation covers how to create, query, and maintain custom data.

A logical organization of entities in the &PRODUCTABBR; data model, used to express how a group of entities from the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service relate to each other in a given real-world scenario.

The process used to import (ingest) a large amount of data to the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service. This is performed using an ingestion utility specifically designed to handle these large, process-intensive operations. Ingestion bypasses the need for a long series of POST operations using the &PRODUCTABBR; REST API.
Any set of data from the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service that's identified by some common feature.
An attribute for an whose purpose is to identify an instance of another entity. Example: A Section entity includes a direct reference of session which identifies a specific Session entity.

A service that manages user identities and those users' roles and permissions within a specific security boundary. Directory service implementations can vary, including anything from a customized OpenLDAP to Microsoft's Active Directory. The &COMPANYABBR; recognizes directory services from an education organization as an authentication resource to which &COMPANYABBR; administrators can map user roles and from which &COMPANYABBR; can authenticate users with those mapped roles.

A generic term used to refer to a level in the hierarchy of education agencies. An education organization may be a state school system, a county/district school system, or an individual school. This documentation may refer to specific education organizations using terms like state education agency (SEA) for state systems and local education agency (LEA) for county/district systems.
One of the user roles in &PRODUCTABBR;. Users with this role can view data only associated with students actively enrolled in current class sections.

The permissions a user has to data after combining the roles that user is assigned to, the rules for which roles take priority, and the specific context from which that user is operating (such as the application the user is using or the current date and time). This can also apply to applications.

The entity component of the industry standard entity-attribute-value model (EAV) used to describe a data model, such as the model for the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service. An entity is the item or object being stored. In &PRODUCTABBR;, each entity in the Secure Data Servicealso corresponds to a resource in the REST API.

An authentication approach in which users authenticate against a directory service that resides outside of the &COMPANYABBR; (provided by the education organization), and the identity of the user is shared with other &COMPANYABBR; applications through use of the SAML protocol. Users can sign in to one &COMPANYABBR; application, and they're automatically signed in to other &COMPANYABBR; applications operating in the same browser.
The &COMPANYABBR; requires that each federated user must map to a Staff or Teacher user entity in &PRODUCTABBR;, created during data ingestion or through the &PRODUCTABBR; REST API.
See also authentication, federated authentication, directory, education organization
A general term used when speaking of a federated state, county, or district school system.

An authentication setup in which multiple different systems that require user authentication are linked together to share a common directory of users. Federation is a common means of providing single sign-on (SSO) functionality across multiple services and applications.
See also authentication
In the &COMPANYABBR;, this term refers to a group of identity providers that the &COMPANYABBR; identity provider trusts.
See also identity provider

A category of data identified by &PRODUCTABBR; for the purpose of assigning all the same permissions to data in that category. Any data not identified as Public data or Restricted data is considered General data.
A term describing something that exists with &PRODUCTABBR; and is managed as part of &PRODUCTABBR;.

A computer system that stores user identity information such as user names, passwords, and roles, and provides a way for other computer systems to access this data. An identity provider may be a directory or a service acting on behalf of one or more directories.
&COMPANYABBR; often uses the common industry abbreviation IDP when referring to an identity provider.

A user responsible for the day-to-day tasks of managing access and data in a deployed &PRODUCT; system. This general term describes two specific &PRODUCTABBR; administrator roles: LEA Administrator and SEA Administrator.
A directory contained within &PRODUCT; used to authenticate users with administrative roles for that &PRODUCT; system, such as an &PRODUCTABBR; Administrator.
One of the &PRODUCTABBR; administrator roles. This role targets users whose responsibility it is to use landing zones and the ingestion application for data ingestion in &PRODUCTABBR;.

Software applications that use the &COMPANYABBR;, but that require the end user to install some amount of the software outside of the &COMPANYABBR;. These are different from web applications, which are network applications that can run in any supported Web browser without installing additional software (except, perhaps, third-party browser plugins such as Flash). Examples of installed applications include mobile and embedded applications.
One of the user roles in &PRODUCTABBR;. Users with this role have all the permissions of users with the Leader roles plus the ability to create new users and to define custom permissions.

An SFTP-accessible directory location that is reserved for files to be ingested using the &COMPANYABBR;'s data ingestion process. &COMPANYABBR; administrators can set up one or more landing zones to serve a single data store.
See also data ingestion
One of the &PRODUCTABBR; administrator roles. This role targets users who serve as &PRODUCTABBR; administrators at the county or district level, below the state level (LEA = local education agency).
One of the user roles in &PRODUCTABBR;. Users with this role can view data related only to those educational organizations to which they're associated.

These are fields whose access by the &PRODUCTABBR; REST API triggers logging an event. This designation is not part of the data model; it currently resides in multiple places within the &PRODUCTABBR; application code.
An attribute that does not require a value in order for the entity to be created or updated in the data store.

An protocol for authorization published as an open standard by Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF). The protocol allows a user to share private resources from one site (web application, network service, etc.) with another site by supplying authentication tokens rather than sharing that user's authentication credentials. The OpenID protocol has similar functionality, but it's distinctly different from OAuth.
&COMPANYABBR; uses the OAuth protocol in combination with SAML.
See also authentication, authorization
An &PRODUCTABBR; administrator role for assigning permissions to users responsible for deploying &PRODUCTABBR; or handling the administrative side of the application registration process.
One of the user roles in &PRODUCTABBR;. Users in the default Parent role group can only view public data, Student_Owned data, and Student_General data.
The rules that govern a user's or application's access to data, such as the education data in the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service

Basic permissions are no access, read-only, and read-write. &PRODUCTABBR; applies these basic permissions to each data point, and related data points are designated by categories. Permissions are assigned to these categories rather than to individual data points. Administrators create roles to manage permissions to these categories, and users receive permissions based on their roles.
See also: effective permissions
Information that can be used, either alone or with other resources, to uniquely identify, contact, or locate a single person.

A category of data identified by &PRODUCTABBR; for the purpose of assigning all the same permissions to data in that category. Data identifes as public data is data that typical education organizations can make available publicly (outside of the organization). Example: A school's street address and phone number.

An &PRODUCTABBR; concept used to identify the context of authentication for a user or application. This can be a district that has its own identity service for authentication, or it could be an organization of districts that share an identity service. The highest available realm is a state. In &PRODUCTABBR;, user IDs are unique only within a tenancy, so it's not recommended that a single realm be used to serve multiple tenants.
One of the &PRODUCTABBR; administrator roles. This role targets users who serve as &PRODUCTABBR; administrators at the realm level.

For user authentication in &COMPANYABBR;, this is a target URI within an application to which a user is redirected after successful authentication. This URI is registered with the &COMPANYABBR; during the application registration process. Also called a callback URL.
An attribute that must have a value in order for the entity to be created or updated in the data store.

Under the industry standard representational state transfer (REST) software architecture, this is any meaningful concept around which a user interaction can occur. Resources in the &PRODUCTABBR; REST API share common fields such as a unique identifier value. Types of resources include Secure Data Serviceentities, event logs, and security administration.
A textual representation of the current state (GET) or intended state (PUT, POST, DELETE) of a resource. The REST API supports JSON and XML representations of resources.

A category of data identified by &PRODUCTABBR; for the purpose of assigning all the same permissions to data in that category. Data identifed as restricted data is data that typical education organizations must keep confidential, whether by law or for the safety of educators and students. Example: A student's status for receiving a free or reduced lunch.
A mapping between a set of permissions and the data to which it applies. A role is typically identified by the title of a group of users that should have that role, such as student or educator.

The process of assigning an authenticated user from the local directory service of an education organization (typically at the state or county/district level) to one of the default roles in &PRODUCTABBR;. This creates what &PRODUCTABBR; refers to as its federated users.

Industry standard term to refer to a non-Production environment where software developers can develop and test their code. The &COMPANYABBR; includes a feature-rich Sandbox environment for use in developing applications to use with the &COMPANYABBR;.
An education organization in &PRODUCTABBR;'s assumed hierarchy of education organizations.
One of the &PRODUCTABBR; administrator roles. This role targets users who serve as &PRODUCTABBR; administrators at the state level (SEA = state education agency).

An XML-based markup language and associated protocol published by the Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards (OASIS). SAML is an open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization betwen security domains. The primary goal of SAML is to facilitate creating a single sign-on (SSO) solution between multiple web applications.
&COMPANYABBR; uses the SAML language in combination with the OAuth protocol.
See also authentication, authorization, security domains.

A virtual security boundary shared by multiple computers, services, and applications. Applications and services within a security domain trust a common security token from an identity provider that serves that domain.

Data in the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Serviceused to record security events, such as events related to signing in and out of the &PRODUCTABBR;, creating or deleting administrators, and accessing certain restricted data.
One of the &PRODUCTABBR; administrator roles. This role targets users whose responsibility it is to use deploy and maintain software in &PRODUCTABBR;.

A user created in &PRODUCTABBR; hosted directory service (within &PRODUCTABBR;) rather than using the external education organization's directory service to which &PRODUCTABBR; is linked. Roles defined under this set of &PRODUCTABBR; administrators include those responsible for setting up and maintaining an &PRODUCTABBR; deployment. See also: &PRODUCTABBR; hosted directory

A directory service that's part of the set of services deployed as part of &PRODUCTABBR;, whose purpose is to manage administrator roles specific to &PRODUCTABBR;. This directory service is considered an internal component of &PRODUCTABBR;, and it's separate from the external directory service to which educators, students, and other people in the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service are mapped.
A field that is a part of a resource representation, as determined by the schema of the resource.
See also common field, view.
One of the user roles in &PRODUCTABBR;. Users in the default Student role group can only view public data, Student_Owned data, and Student_General data.
The set of data that a given user has administrative access to based on that user's combination of roles and context.
For specific use when assigning user roles, see Tenant.

A single set of self-consistent data that is logically isolated within the &PRODUCTABBR; Secure Data Service. A single state-level education organization is a tenancy, and it is possible for multiple other tenancies (for multiple county/district education organizations) exist within the same state.
See also: tenancy

An identifying object, typically a string of characters, that's unique among all objects within a given system. The unique identifier for objects in the &COMPANYABBR; Secure Data Sevices are structured similar to the UUID standard (set by the Open Software Foundation), but deviate from that standard by adding to that ID string.
The process by which an administrator for &PRODUCTABBR; adds new users to the system, including assigning roles to those users for the purpose of determining the user's effective permissions.

A code that verifies that the credentials provided by a user have been authenticated against the identity directory that contains that user's account. A verification code enables your application to obtain an access token.
A set of data that extends the view of the original resource. By default, a GET request to the &RESTAPI; does not return views. A global parameter can be used to request views.
See also common field, standard field, resource.
